What are the characteristics of the third homogeneous cause?
Verse:
Homogeneous causes are similar, arising before in the same realm,
The path is mutually nine grounds, only equal and superior are the fruits,
The same is true for causes of added effort and birth, such as those accomplished through hearing and contemplation.
Discussion:
The homogeneous causes are those that nourish, give birth, or are distant or near, and are the homogeneous effects.
One should know that this cause is only for similar dharmas, and for similar dharmas, not for dissimilar categories.

For example, the five aggregates of good [karma] are mutually related to the five aggregates of good [karma] as homogeneous causes. It should be known that the defiled and indeterminate [aggregates] are also like this.
Some other masters say:
The pure and nondetermined aggregates are the effect of form, but the four aggregates are not the cause of form, because their nature is inferior.
Other masters say:
The five aggregates are the four effects, but form is not the four causes, because its power is inferior.
Other masters say:
Form and the four aggregates are not causes for each other, because they are inferior and of different species.
If we speak in terms of stages, other masters say:
The kalala stage can be the similar cause for the ten stages.
The nine stages of arbuda, etc., each exclude the former stage and are causes for the remaining stages. The later stages have only the meaning of condition in relation to the earlier ones.
If this is so, then the initial form of the kalala stage would have no cause, and the final form of the old stage would have no effect, and therefore this interpretation is not correct.
Other masters say:
The ten stages that have already arisen are each the similar cause for the form of their own species in the ten stages that will arise.
On the basis of this principle, all external forms should be discussed in terms of their own species.

Their assertion contradicts what is said in the Abhidharma treatise. Therefore, the Abhidharma treatise says:

Only those of the same category and stage are causes for those of the same category and stage. Therefore it is said of the same category and stage.

Stage refers to the nine stages, namely the desire realm as one, and the dhyanas and formless [realms] as eight.

Here, those abandoned by seeing suffering in the desire realm are homogeneous causes for those abandoned by seeing suffering in the desire realm. In this way, up to those abandoned by cultivation in the desire realm are causes for those abandoned by cultivation in the desire realm.
As it is said for the five categories abandoned in the desire realm, so it is said for the four stages in the dhyanas and formless [realms] as appropriate.

That is, only the prior one is a homogeneous cause for similar dharmas that are subsequent and not yet arisen. This is called the complete characteristic of a homogeneous cause.

If one only says that the prior one is a homogeneous cause for the subsequent one that has arisen, there is a deficiency in the meaning, because it does not say that it is a homogeneous cause for that which has not yet arisen.
If one only says that the past is a homogeneous cause for the future and present, there is also a deficiency in the meaning, because it does not say that the past has a cause and effect.

The similar cause is established on the basis of priority and posteriority, but when a dharma is in the process of being born, it has already passed through the future and has not yet had the activity of a present dharma. It is like other future dharmas.

Also, the mind of transformation of the realm of desire has the four trances as a result. The result of the lower trance is not the cause of the higher trance. The result of a cause that is a preparatory practice is not a lower result. Do not say that one obtains nothing by setting up effort.
Because of this interpretation, there is a question:
Is there a case in which all dharmas that are already born are not the cause of dharmas that are not yet born?

Yes, that is, the class of knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering that has already arisen is not the similar cause for the class of perseverance for knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering that has not yet arisen in its own life-stream. In this way, up to the class of diamond-like samÄdhi that has already arisen is not the similar cause for the pure dharmas that have not yet arisen in its own life-stream or in a lower stage.
Moreover, all superior dharmas are the similar cause for all inferior dharmas. The results obtained are either equal or superior.
Can there be any pure dharmas in a single life-stream that are definitely obtained first and are not the cause for those that arise later?

Yes, that is, the class of perseverance for knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering in the future is not the similar cause for the class of knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering that has already arisen, because the result must never precede the cause, or because there are no similar causes in the future.
Can there be any pure dharmas that have already arisen in the past that are not the cause for pure dharmas that have already arisen?

There is, namely, the previously arisen superior pure dharmas, in relation to the later arisen inferior pure dharmas. For example, the obtainment of the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering that has already arisen is in relation to the obtainment of the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering that has already arisen. Although the latter arises later, it is inferior.
In this way, all the obtainments of the holy paths are superior in the former and inferior in the later. This should be understood by analogy.

Here the author of the commentary answers the question by saying that when one falls away from the fruit of a higher stage, the fruit of a lower stage becomes manifest. This is not definite, because after falling away from the fruit of a higher stage, one may still sharpen one's faculties and give rise to superior pure dharmas that become manifest.
He should distinguish this.
However, the function of this type of cause in producing its effect is inexhaustible, unlike the function of the cause of retribution in producing its effect, which is definitely exhausted.
Because all arhats who receive the type of cause have not yet exhausted the effect, and because they enter nirvana, the type of cause definitely cannot produce its effect.
This means that there is a type of cause that, due to the presence of obstacles, its effect may arise at another time or never arise.
Therefore, there is a question here:
Can a similar cause also take a result while giving a result?
The general answer is:
Those that give results must also be able to take results.
Why is this?
It is unreasonable that they give without taking.
There can be taking of results without giving, such as the final aggregates of an arhat. Although previous aggregates can give results, they have not yet been exhausted when one enters parinirvÄá¹‡a.

Moreover, although the preparatory actions of listening, reciting, and contemplation are the same, and one encounters the same auxiliary conditions, one sees that the accumulation of wholesome roots is different. Therefore, we know that the function of causes is not limited to this life.
However, it is said that wholesome roots arise due to the power of the wholesome roots that accompany them, which is stated in terms of accomplishment.
This statement means that although causes can give rise to results both when accomplished and when not accomplished, those that are accomplished have a strong power to give rise to results.
Although there are differences in strength, the meaning of being a cause is the same.
Also, though both proximate and distant causes are accomplished, there is still a difference in their superiority and inferiority in relation to the production of effects.

Therefore, the similar and immediately antecedent condition is in terms of the function of receiving and using effects without exhaustion, not in terms of the cause of retribution.
Where has this principle ever been explained?
Isn't it explained in the discussion of the characteristics of causes that the future, present, and past are causes, and the past and present are causes for the future?
What is the reason for blocking the similar and immediately antecedent condition for the mind and mental factors of an arhat at the very moment of death?
Allowing the nature of similar and immediately antecedent conditions, these two are equal in producing effects, not simultaneously.
The similar and immediately antecedent condition is by the power of making way.

When arhats are about to die, there are no mind and mental factors that arise immediately after, because the causes and conditions for their arising are lacking. However, the cause and effect of the same type are both near and far. Moreover, the effect that is attracted has no limit. The effect that is not to be taken up is not necessarily to arise. Therefore it cannot be compared to the immediately antecedent condition to prohibit the establishment of the nature of the same type cause in the later stage.
There is another explanation:
It is definitely only in the immediately antecedent effect that the same type cause is established.

Moreover, it should not be said that the position of the arising of good, bad, and indeterminate minds next is not due to the previous moment being the same type cause for the arising of the next moment mind, because it is seen in the world that dissimilar things such as seeds, sprouts, stems, leaves, buds, flowers, and fruits arise in sequence when arising, arising immediately after as the cause, and arising in sequence, without interruption.

Their explanation is unreasonable, because we actually see that when one of good or bad increases, the other decreases.
Also, if the cultivated antidote and the object of the antidote increase, then there would never be liberation from suffering.
Also, if the object of the antidote and the antidote increase, then there would be no one who does not become a path of the antidote.
They cannot avoid such errors.

Also, we see that in the world, when one studies writing, treatises, skills, and other knowledge, and has already attained stability, even though one encounters other conditions and gives rise to other things in the meantime, when one is born later, one still uses the same kind of continuity from the previous time as a cause to give rise to them. Therefore the similar and immediately antecedent condition also has a gap.

The example of seeds, sprouts, etc. is not able to prove this. The sequence of the arising and abiding of external things is different from that of internal dharmas. Therefore the example is not able to prove the point.
For example, a sprout definitely arises immediately after a seed, not a stem, leaves, etc. We do not see a mind definitely arising in the same way immediately after a good mind.
Also, a stem can arise immediately after a sprout, but a sprout cannot arise immediately after a stem.
The order in which good and bad minds arise is not fixed.
Moreover, external things are determined by time, but internal dharmas are not. Therefore, the analogy is not adequate.

That is to say, due to the power of function, diligence, teaching, etc., the mind of good dharmas of the practitioner of contemplation continues for a long time, and the mind of those who cultivate desires continues for a long time. The time of sprouts, stems, etc. is not fixed. Therefore, internal and external are different.
Moreover, the class of rice, etc., has the same indeterminate nature in the sequence of arising, and can have the meaning of cause;
The class of mind, etc., has the difference of good nature, etc. in the sequence of arising, and should not be used as an analogy.
As for the saying that reeds grow from the horns of a rabbit, this is a worldly discussion that contradicts reason.
If you allow that there is no distinction between similar and dissimilar in the arising of characteristics, why do you not allow that two each arise from two fruits?

However, the horns of a rabbit, like the warmth of excrement, etc., only act as favorable conditions in the arising of reeds. Therefore, similar causes are only established as causes for their own class, whether there is an interval or not.
Thus the characteristics of similar causes have been explained.
What are the characteristics of the fourth, the associated cause?
Verse:
The associated cause is definitely the mind and mental factors that rely on the same basis.
Commentary:
Only the mind and mental factors are the associated cause.
Isn't it so that there is no distinction in this [verse], and therefore time, object, and mode of activity are also associated even if different?

Even if one makes a distinction and says that these three are the same, the association of different bodies with the same entrustment should be said to be association, and therefore it is said that they rely on the same basis.
This generally refutes this difficulty, namely, that the mind and mental factors must rely on the same basis in order to be mutually the associated cause.

The word same here shows that the basis is one. That is to say, if the eye consciousness uses this moment of eye faculty as its basis, the associated feelings, etc. also use this eye faculty as their basis. Up to the mental consciousness and the associated dharmas using the mind faculty as their basis should be understood in the same way.
Now we should contemplate:
The eye, ear, etc., are the same in being the support of consciousness. Why is it said that the support of the consciousness that depends on them is different?
Why bother to ask?
Although the support of the various consciousnesses is the same in nature, the species are different.
If this is so, why is it known that the expression â€œsame supportâ€ refers only to the support in the same moment of arising?
It is said that eye consciousness, etc., have the same support, but this is said in terms of a support that is the same species, not in terms of a support that is the same for a long time.
Also, because the immediately antecedent support is the same in species, eye consciousness, etc., should be similar and immediately antecedent conditions for each other.
The World Honored One also speaks of the support in terms of the same species, because a scripture says,
When the eye sees forms, sorrow, joy, and indifference are produced.
Also, a scripture says,
The eye is the gate for seeing forms only.
All these passages speak of the same support in terms of the same species. Therefore the verse should be amended to read, Mind and its activities are simultaneous and the same in support.
Therefore, the above explanation includes two meanings: if eye consciousness uses this moment of eye faculty as its support, and so on.
Since the verse lacks the word simultaneous, how can we know that the common support here is not of the same kind and is of one moment?

If it is said that there is no error because it is included in the explanation, then the composed verse should not speak of common support, but should only speak of the associated cause as definitely being mind and mental factors.
Moreover, the word associated is sufficient to block all difficulties. It is possible to be associated with different supports at different times.
But by speaking only of association, we know that all times, supports, aspects, objects, and events are the same.
If the supports, aspects, and objects are different at different times, they are not associated. Therefore, they are not of the same kind and many events do not arise together.
Because they are associated, what is the difference between the two causes of co-existence and association?

First, the cause of association is also the cause of co-existence. There is the cause of co-existence that is not the cause of association, namely the derivative form that is the transformation of the great elements, such as birth.
If the similar and immediately antecedent condition is the simultaneous and interactive condition, what is the difference between the meanings of these two conditions?
The similar and immediately antecedent condition is not the simultaneous and interactive condition, because the meanings of these two conditions are different.

However, a single dharma is both the similar and immediately antecedent condition and the simultaneous and interactive condition. The difference in meaning is that the meaning of non-separation is the similar and immediately antecedent condition, and the meaning of the same effect is the simultaneous and interactive condition.

Moreover, the power of mutual dependence in the same birth, abiding, etc. is the simultaneous and interactive condition. If the power of mutual dependence is the same in relying on a single object, it is the similar and immediately antecedent condition.
Other masters say:
The simultaneous and interactive condition is established by the meaning of being mutually results, like merchants relying on each other to travel together on a dangerous road.

The similar and immediately antecedent condition is established by the meaning of the five equalities, namely, like merchants equally receiving and equally performing the work of eating, etc. If one of them is missing, they are all not similar and immediately antecedent. Therefore, the meaning of being mutually conditions is fully established.
Thus, the characteristics of the similar and immediately antecedent condition have been explained.
What are the characteristics of the fifth, the universal condition?
Verse:
The universal is said to be the preceding, which is the cause of defilement in the same stage.
The treatise says:

The universal cause refers to the already arisen universal latent afflictions and the dharmas of the same category, which are the universal cause for the defiled dharmas of the same stage belonging to one's own and other categories.
What are called the dharmas of the universal category?
They will be extensively distinguished in the chapter on latent afflictions.
This cause surpasses the power of the homogeneous cause and operates, therefore it is separately established.
It is also the cause of the defiled dharmas of other categories, because by its power, the afflictions and their retinue of other categories also arise and grow.
Among the afflictions included in one's own category, how are the two causes of the homogeneous and the universal different?
Because of the view of the aggregates, the craving arises, and the craving is also able to give rise to the view of the aggregates. How can the difference between the two be known?
The two causes in one's own category also have differences. That is to say, because of grasping the self, it is able to make the craving arise, become firm, increase, expand, and flourish.

Because the view of self takes all objects of craving as its object, craving causes the view of self to arise, to be firm, but it cannot cause it to increase and expand, because it cannot take the objects of the view of self as its object.

Because all pervasive afflictions mutually take each other as objects, they can all take all objects as their objects. Therefore each pervasive affliction can cause the arising, firmness, increase, and expansion of the other.
Therefore these two causes are not without distinctions.
What is the distinction between the two causes of similar type and universal cause, which are able to be causes in one moment and one stage?

Although they simultaneously take the two results of similar cause at the same time, the results of one's own category are more abundant than those of other categories. Therefore the two causes also have distinctions.
Why are the results of one's own category more abundant?
Because they are nourished by the two causes, because they are the proximate causes for their arising, and because they cause them to increase and expand.
Why are the two causes distinguished as only giving rise to one's own category?
Because there is no universal cause, it only gives rise to one's own category.
When a universal dharma is present, it has the power to take the fruits of the five classes of karma simultaneously.
Moreover, it has already been explained that they are distinguished in the following way.
Other masters say:
A part of co-existent causes is associated causes, and a part of homogeneous causes is universal causes.

The meaning of the universal cause is the same as that of the homogeneous cause. However, this is unreasonable, because other schools would also be homogeneous causes, and then they would not be universal causes. They should be homogeneous causes in relation to other schools. In that case, all causes would become confused.
Even though the various causes do not have separate substances, the meanings of the various causes are not confused with each other.

If universal dharmas are the causes of the defiled dharmas of the five classes, then the cause of the dharmas that are eliminated by insight should be all defiled dharmas. This is what we accept, and it should not be a problem.

What are the dharmas whose cause is eliminated by insight?
It means the karmic maturation that is attracted by defiled dharmas and dharmas that are to be eliminated by the path of insight.
What are the dharmas that have indeterminate causes?
It means the indeterminate conditioned dharmas and the unwholesome dharmas.

Or, there is the truth of suffering that has the view of self as its cause, but is not a cause for the view of self. Speaking in detail, it is like this: except for the future view of self and the arising, old age, and impermanence of dharmas associated with it, the remaining defiled truth of suffering.

Is there any unwholesome dharma that has only unwholesome dharmas as its causes?

There is. It refers to the defiled volition that arises for the first time when an arhat falls away from the state of having eliminated desire. Based on the cause of what has not yet been eliminated, this is said in a hidden manner.

Although the causes of this defiled volition are both non-good and indeterminate, the indeterminate causes have already been eternally eliminated, because the saintly person in the stage of regression has already eliminated the passions that are eliminated by the path of insight. Because all the paths of insight are without regression, because the indeterminate passions of the realm of desire are all eliminated by the path of insight, and because only the causes of non-good are eliminated by regression. Therefore, there is no error in saying that they are not yet eliminated.

Because the views of annihilation, false views, and the view of the aggregates as real selves have already been eliminated, craving for nonexistence, etc., arise in succession to them.
How can they be causes in the present?

It is not that they become causes in the present. In the state of ordinary being, the defiled dharmas eliminated by the path of cultivation already use as their causes the universal proclivities eliminated by the path of insight.
If a dharma is a cause of another dharma, there is no time when it is not a cause of that dharma. Therefore, although it has already been eliminated, it can still be said to be a cause.

It should be understood that past and present pervasive latent afflictions are causes of the five categories, can take the five categories as objects, and are also that which increases in the five categories.
The dharmas associated with them, excluding that which increases, and also excluding that which takes the five categories as objects,
the acquisitions of those dharmas are not pervasive causes, either because they are sequential or because their nature is distant, or because they are not of the same fruit.
There are pervasive latent afflictions that are not pervasive causes, namely future pervasive latent afflictions.
There are pervasive causes that are not pervasive latent afflictions, namely past and present pervasive latent afflictions of the same fruit.
There are those that are both, namely past and present pervasive latent afflictions.
There are those that are neither, namely the remaining dharmas.
There are those who raise objections to this, saying:

If you say that the various views, doubt, and ignorance are universal causes that generate results of different kinds, because they are different from the other passions, then the universal seeds are not also the function of the other passions. For example, the proclivity of craving is attached to an object and is the root of all false practices. When there is false view, the proclivity of craving is attached to objects and becomes rampant. When there is craving, it also causes false views to increase and expand with regard to their own objects, and finally it causes the cutting off of good roots.

When there is false view, it denies cessation and the path, and then it causes the proclivity of craving to delight in saá¹ƒsÄra. When there is craving and one delights in saá¹ƒsÄra, it can cause false views to deny cessation and the path.

Therefore, it is definitely not reasonable to maintain that only views, doubt, and ignorance are universal causes that generate results of the five classes of passions, and that the others, such as craving, are not.
This objection is not reasonable, because the function of the causes is different.
The proclivities are not universal.

In general, the five classes of defiled dharmas are the efficient and dominant effects of the passions, because they can be the condition as cause for each other and make each other appear, and because they do not obstruct each other when they are born.

The omnipresent secondary passions also have the five classes of defiled dharmas as their similar and immediate effects. What is the difference between these two kinds of passions that they are treated differently?

The omnipresent secondary passions are able to take as objects all impure dharmas, and therefore their power is firm, strong, and extensive. As soon as they are born, they are able to attract and project results of the same and different species.
The non-omnipresent secondary passions are not like this, because they take as objects a limited number of dharmas and their power is weak.

Even though the secondary passion of craving is attached to an object, it still becomes the condition as cause for false views, etc., and even attracts the cutting off of the roots of good, but it does not temporarily produce and attract as its similar and immediate effect the five classes of defiled dharmas of oneself and others.

The latent tendency of craving for existence, having already enjoyed cyclic existence, can lead to wrong views that deny cessation and the path. This is because they mutually lead to each other within the same group, not to different groups. Therefore there is no contradiction.
Or else, the meaning of cause is very profound and difficult to understand, with countless distinctions that are not easy to know.

What are the characteristics of the sixth, the cause of karmic retribution?
Verse:
Retribution causes are unwholesome and wholesome, and only have outflows.
The treatise says:
Only unwholesome and wholesome dharmas with outflows are retribution causes, because they are dharmas with retribution.
According to their respective capacities, these causes are able to attract retribution results, and are therefore called retribution causes.
What is the meaning of cause in this context?
It means that according to the dharmas that accompany karma, sentient beings are distinguished. Therefore a sutra says:
The superiority and inferiority of sentient beings is due to the distinction of karma.
Also, a sutra says:
Karma is the cause of birth.

The word only in the verse is to exclude the notion that the substance of retribution causes includes all causes. There are other teachers who say that all results are called retribution. They also should admit that the substance of retribution causes includes all causes.
The word only is to prevent the same as such other teachers' arbitrary conceptions.
For what reason do they conceive that all results are called retribution?
Because a scripture says:
What is the retribution of this great light?

The two kinds of food that are given lead to retribution that is equal, equal.

If the TathÄgata had not spoken these words, then the various assemblies would not have had such retribution.

How do we know that the former is also metaphorically said?

Also, the scriptures say:

because it is not moistened by craving, it is like a seed that is not moistened by water.
Also, since pure dharmas are not categorized as belonging to any realm, how can they attract a retribution that belongs to a realm?

Because it is weak, like rotten seeds.
Other good and bad actions can summon retribution, like moist seeds.
However, the cause of retribution is sometimes explained as a compound word, so the scriptures say:
The eye born of retribution.
Sometimes it is explained as a dependent word, so the scriptures say:
The retribution of karma.
The meaning is as previously explained.

Or it means that when the created karma reaches the time of obtaining the effect, it transforms and ripens. This one belongs to the cause.
However, the teacher of the scriptures says:
The VaibhÄá¹£ika masters explain it like this: The meaning of retribution is that it ripens as a different kind.

Sometimes one aggregate is the cause of retribution and produces one result, namely, the attainment of non-perdition and its characteristics.
Sometimes two aggregates are the cause of retribution and produce one result, namely, good and bad form and its characteristics.
Sometimes four aggregates are the cause of retribution and produce one result, namely, good and bad mind and mental activities and their characteristics.
Because there is no form in the realm of desire that is concomitant with the four aggregates, there is no case of five aggregates being the cause of retribution and producing one result.

That which gives rise to them and that which is given rise to are not necessarily simultaneous, and therefore the results that are produced are not necessarily simultaneous.

Sometimes four aggregates are the homogeneous cause and produce one result, namely, the good mind and mental factors and their origination, etc., that are not concomitant with form.

Sometimes five aggregates are the homogeneous cause and produce one result, namely, the good mind and mental factors and their origination, etc., that are concomitant with form.
In the formless realm, sometimes one aggregate is the homogeneous cause and produces one result, namely, the attainment of cessation and its origination, etc.
Sometimes four aggregates are the homogeneous cause and produce one result, namely, all good mind and mental factors.
Thus there are nine homogeneous causes in all, namely, three types in the three realms, in the order of three, four, and two, respectively, with distinctions of type.
There is karma that produces only one sphere as its matured effect, namely, the dharma sphere, which is the life faculty, etc.
If it produces the mental faculty, it definitely produces two spheres, namely, the mental faculty and the dharma sphere.
If it produces the tangible medium, you should know that it also produces two media, namely, the tangible medium and the dharma medium.
If it produces the visible medium, it definitely produces three media, namely, the visible, tangible, and dharma media.
If it produces the odor or taste medium, you should know that it also produces three media, namely, each of these two, plus the tangible and dharma media.
If it produces the body medium, it definitely produces four media, namely, the body, visible, tangible, and dharma media.
If it produces the eye medium, it definitely produces five media, namely, the eye, body, visible, tangible, and dharma media.
You should know that the same is true of the production of the ear, nose, and tongue media, namely, each of these is one, plus the body, visible, tangible, and dharma media.
There is karma that produces six, seven, eight, nine, ten, or eleven media.
Sound is not retribution, and therefore it is not discussed here. Karma may have few media as its result or many media as its result.

Just as an external seed may have few fruits or many fruits. For example, the seed of a lotus has many different fruits, such as roots, sprouts, stems, flowers, pistils, leaves, etc., but the seed of a grape is not like this.

The seeds of the class of grasses and trees have many roots, stems, branches, leaves, and flowers, and their fruits are different. There are various kinds of grasses and trees that grow in water or on land, and their species have only one stem, such as the needle grass, etc.
Or they have only leaves and no stems, etc., and their seeds are naturally so. One should not ask questions about this.
